utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.sentences: You vape as a national pastime, so before you start talking about --

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: That needs to be --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That should be an event.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I can -- I can inhale --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The vape cloud. You get judged by the vape cloud.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I would win.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Of course you would. Of course you would. And they could -- you know what, that'd be great they could have it in San Francisco where it's banned.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Tyrus, what are your thoughts on this? It feels like sports are just arbitrary. Well, it's like why is baseball a sport?

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.sentences: I'm not going to get into that with you. Baseball is a great American pastime, communist. But here's the thing, the Olympics is -- it's dying and where they're trying to inject it with stuff to keep the old horse going, but at some point you've got to take Boxer to the glue factory. It's just the way it is. Breakdancing is an art form. You know, I put it up there with gymnastics and stuff, so I get it. I'm good with breakdancing. Badminton not so much, but you know the Olympics is trying to keep people going because once the Summer Olympics in this kind of thing, you see track and field and stuff. But countries as they progress and get better, they have their own sports now. And people don't -- the best athletes don't necessarily train for the Olympics. So it's kind of an -- it's an old pastime, but it's fading away. So eventually at some point it'll be video games. It'll be your face timing, speed texting. It will be things like that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Selfies. You could be judged on how well you disguise your flaws. Like that athlete comes out without makeup and then they do a selfie and if you can see how much better they are without actually knowing that they did anything. What am I talking about?

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.sentences: You know you're onto something. It's one hundred percent. That's where the Olympics is going.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Or how about this? Speed texting, because like with the least error so you have like five people there and you have like a passage from "Paradise Lost" and they have to speak text it to their friend without -- with few errors.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I would win.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You would? Would you win?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: A thousand percent.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So there you go. See. It's right up your alley.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: And here I thought I was not an athlete.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know, Tom, I bet you might have had some breakdancing in your background.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.sentences: I was a bit of a break dancer.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, I could see that.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.sentences: Yes, I was a bit of a foot looser, too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, were you?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.sentences: Yes, I went to the art of feet loosing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.sentences: Yes, letting those feet loose.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.sentences: But I --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Did you dismember people?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.sentences: I never did that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.sentences: But, I thought about it. No. I used to hate the sports that had the judges. I like things that have finite, you know, rules to them. You know, if you run the fastest you get the gold medal. And I didn't think that anything that had judges in it should be in the Olympics, but now I do like the judging because it really shows you that there's no such thing as objectivity because the judges from Russia always give the Russian person the highest score.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.sentences: And it shows you there's no objectivity in the world.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This is why as I've said before, all judges whether it's in sports, or in real life, have to be at robots or artificial intelligence, or what do you call those? What are those little things?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: You're going to have to be more specific.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Algorithms.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Of course.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Because judges when they're like deciding whether you go to jail or not, it depends on whether they had lunch. There's research on that how much you ate affects whether you're going to get like pardons or early release and the same -- I mean, it's like it's so -- I mean, think about that? You've got to have -- it's the same thing with the Olympics. They've got to be judges.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.sentences: It also shows you, if you ever get arrested and you go into court bring a sandwich.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So true. So true. We learn a lot from you, Tom. All right. Don't forget to buy your tickets for "The Gutfeld Monologues Live." The next three shows: July 20th, Asbury Park, New Jersey; September 14th in Orlando; September 15th, Atlanta. Special guest some jerk named Tom Shillue. Go to ggutfeld.com for ticket info. Stay right there. I have a very special "Final Thought" to close out tonight's show.

utterances.speaker: ANNOUNCER
utterances.sentences: "Final Thoughts." It's the last thought. That's why it's called the "Final Thoughts," okay.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. We've got two. One from Joe, go for it.

utterances.speaker: MACHI
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Greg. I just want to give a quick shout out to my friends at the Jared Box Project. What they do is they make up boxes of games and toys for kids fight in the hospital. It's Jared Box, thejaredbox.com. J- A-R-E-D. If you'd like to make a donation or get involved. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Nicely done. All right. So I have a "Final Thought." We are saying goodbye to a very important member of the staff. Come here. She is just going to cry. I know she is going to cry. Don't cry. Our studio audience coordinator, Nora Torpey. If you've ever been to a live show, which I think about 20,000 people have at this point, it's because Nora puts you there. Whenever you sent e-mails that were yelling about something, she was the one who had to read it and be nice to you. She's the one that always deals with cranky people who have to pee. She worked with us back in the "Red Eye" days and she's been a big part of this show's success. And we're going to miss you Nora. Give Nora a hand, everyone.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. Special thanks to Tom Shillue, Joe Machi, Kat, Tyrus and studio audience. Nora Torpey. I'm Greg Gutfeld. I love you, America. utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello. And welcome to our special July 4th weekend show. It's brand new, but was pre-taped a week ago.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Which means tonight, whatever topic I choose to discuss, it has to be interesting and fun, but also generic and non-topical so it doesn't get old in a week. So how about those Democrats?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: See, that never gets old. It never gets old. Deviling and not mailing it in tonight. Yes, all of these Democrats, they want to be President and they are trying desperately to stand out while trying to appear human. They drink beer, just like you and me.

utterances.speaker: SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN, D-MASS., PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: Hold on a sec, I'm going to get me a beer. Hey, my husband, Bruce is now in here. You want a beer?

utterances.speaker: BRUCE MANN, HUSBAND OF ELIZABETH WARREN
utterances.utterance: No, I'll pass on the beer tonight.

utterances.speaker: WARREN
utterances.utterance: I'll pull a stool and sit down.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I will never drink beer again.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They also go to the dentist, just like you and me.

utterances.speaker: BETO O'ROURKE, D-PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: So, I'm here at the dentist and we're going to continue our series on the people of the border and I'm here with Diana, my dental hygienist. Diana is going to tell us a little bit about growing up in Memphis.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They watch porn with their mom, just like you and me.

utterances.speaker: JOHN HICKENLOOPER, D-PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: I promised her that we would go to the movie theater and see this new movie. It's an X movie, I don't know -- you know, I just -- I was sure that she wouldn't say no. I made a mistake. So I took my mother to see "Deep Throat."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What voting bloc was he trying to win over with that story? The crazy pervert who goes to pornos with his mom voting bloc? It's a huge bloc. Great story though. Well, when you've got 20 candidates in the mix, at some point, it starts to feel like a bunch of retreads, all trying to outdo themselves with applause lines for the left-wing fringe on Twitter. Trump didn't do any of that as a candidate. He stood at the podium, got the crowd fired up, no one bulldozed past him to get to the condiments.

utterances.speaker: SEN. KIRSTEN GILLIBRAND, D-N.Y., PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: I don't think you should back away from the bold ideas that the base and the grassroots care about --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Sorry, ma'am. I'm just trying to get some Ranch.

utterances.speaker: GILLIBRAND
utterances.utterance: Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No. Ranch always gets applause. Ranch always gets -- and you didn't see Trump doing this.

utterances.speaker: O'ROURKE
utterances.utterance: They're all excited this morning. They were talking about how many days are left in the school year. We're cutting out some of this ear hair that you get when you get older. It grows out of your ears and you don't get it cut, it can be nasty.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, the day we see how Trump's hair is done, it will be a hundred dollar pay-per-view event. And I would watch the hell out of it. I don't need to see Beto's ear hair. I don't need to see Beto. Much less, his ear hair. But Trump didn't need to do that. He packed the stadium and had a strong rallying cry.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT
utterances.utterance: We will make America great again. Thank you. Thank you very much. Thank you. We will make America great again. Thank you. Thank you very much. We will make America great again.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Now that was his slogan, but what does the other side have?

utterances.speaker: REP. ERIC SWALWELL, D-CALIF., PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: I will be bold without the bull.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Silence. Of all the candidates in this race, I think I'm going to miss him the most. And of course, there's Joe.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, D-PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: My name is Joe Biden and I am running, in this case, running for President of the United States. Look me over. If you like what you see, help out. If not, vote for the other person.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think they are going to vote for the other person. I don't know what's worse that Joe is so tired or that he was still the front runner after that. But do you know who doesn't sound tired?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: You know who got me elected? You know who got me elected? I got me elected.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Such a bad ass. Right now, that's what this election is coming down to. This is Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And this is any one of the Democrats.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I need to get that back. The fact is, Trump has made it hard to judge anyone just on politics. It's probably the greatest unintentional benefit of his presidency. Sure, we've got a great economy and low unemployment, but we're seeing something else happening, a challenge to the stereotypes, the platitudes, the cliches. The Old Guard feels so tired and lame, which is why I know who Trump is going to face in 2020.

utterances.speaker: MARIANNE WILLIAMSON, D-PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: Mr. President, if you're listening, I want you to hear me, please. You have harnessed fear for political purposes and only love can cast that out. So, I, sir, I have a feeling you know what you're doing. I'm going to harness love for political purposes. I will meet you on that field and, sir, love will win.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ANNOUNCER
utterances.utterance: Period.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Let's welcome tonight's guests. He is bland he makes Pat Boone seem dangerous. Host of the "Quiz Show" on Fox Nation, Tom Shillue.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He performs his service even if he is super nervous, comedian, Joe Machi.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: She is a sassy but keeps it classy. Host of "Sincerely, Kat" on Fox Nation, Katherine Timpf.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And he finished a marathon in just 12 steps. My massive sidekick and host of "Nuff Said" on Fox Nation, Tyrus.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Tom, what's your assessment in this race so far?

utterances.speaker: TOM SHILLUE, CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: What do you mean you're going to miss Swalwell? He is not out of it, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I am assuming he will be out of it.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: He is going strong.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You like Swalwell?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: I like Swalwell because I just want my slogan, I want Trump to use my slogan. What would you rather have? A swell wall or a Swalwell?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: I actually said that on this show, Greg, and then I went to this big Fox Nation event, people had buttons that had my slogan on it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's what happens. That's what happens. It's one of the few things you'll be remembered for. It could be the only thing you'll be remembered for because you are forgettable.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: There's an always an "Oh" when I am on this show.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Joe? I'm kidding, Tom. Barely. Joe, what's you're take so far on the Democratic candidates. Which one scares you at least?

utterances.speaker: JOE MACHI, COMEDIAN
utterances.utterance: I'll tell you what, Andrew Yang scares me the least because he is going to give me a thousand dollars for nothing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACHI
utterances.utterance: And that sounds good. That's the only candidate that's going to give me money to pay for all the tax increases I am going to have to pay to pay for everything for everybody else.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Kat?

utterances.speaker: KATHERINE TIMPF, CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: Yes, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What are your thoughts?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: My thoughts?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Put them in order of importance.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I mean, if I could have anything in the world, I would have Marianne Williamson be the Democratic nominee.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Me too.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Because I mean, she is just -- I have friends like her, right? And I see them about once every six months because it's a little bit harder to talk to your problems -- talk about your problems with someone who is just going to say, "Well, just rub crystals on your knees, and they'll go away." Or you know, well, that's because the moon is in Bijushabi and when the Bijushabi is in retrograde, and then Bejitude, a Scorpio moon, Libra cusp and -- that's what it sounds like to me. I don't really know, but people believe this and they have a certain kind of face in talking when they do.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I know.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: And it's like, she is like, love. She can't just say, like if I say the word "love" it's like not as sexy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. It's so soothing. It's like when you hear her, I feel like I am bathing in a tub of warm milk, Tyrus, and I know that feeling because I often do that when I am home alone. GEORGE "TYRUS" MURDOCH, CONTRIBUTOR: That's the least appealing thing I think I've ever heard.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, I've got more.

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.utterance: Boy. So you want to talk about the Democrats or you want to stay weird in the bathroom? What do you want to do?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Let's talk about the Democrats.

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.utterance: Honestly, I'm surprised. Weird in the bathroom is a little more fun.

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.utterance: I haven't -- there's been some moments. I just -- I keep looking at former Vice President, Mr. Joe Biden and go, "Why are you doing this yourself? Nobody likes you." Like I feel -- and at the same time, it's also a big moment for me because, I never in my lifetime thought people would gang up and tell white people they are not allowed. This is this is great for me, like, wow, we've come a long way. We kind of went too far. Back up and let everybody be cool, but I just want every -- I can't watch more than a few minutes of it. Because every time Cory Booker talks, I think, just say what you want to say, but he can't. Because he has to be the guy that everybody likes. He's everybody's friend, which to me means he is nobody's friend. So people like that you just can't trust.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, I believe -- I believe that the ticket is -- and I am predicting it now is going to be two women. Because I think that like -- the strongest candidates are Kamala and Liz. It's just which one is going to be --

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Isn't it weird that I'm not inspired by that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No. It's not --

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I am a woman, but I prefer to like keep my money, you know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well on that note, coming up, we answer your mail and then throw Tom Shillue out a window.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's time for viewer mail, a highly original segment that happens on holiday shows. Here are just a handful of the hundreds you submitted on Facebook and Twitter. And as always, these are directed to everyone including myself. Peggy Sue writes, you don't hear a lot of Peggy Sue's anymore, ever since she got married. If you could go back in time to visit a younger version of yourself, what advice would you give and what age would you visit? Tyrus?

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.utterance: Eighteen, I'll be, quick kid, vasectomy, safe with anything. Trust no one.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Vasectomy. Kat.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Just all the teens, and I would tell myself that maybe if you didn't sit in the classroom writing song lyrics on your notebook about how nobody likes you more people might like you. It's okay, I'm all right now, guys.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Joe?

utterances.speaker: MACHI
utterances.utterance: That's a tough one, Greg. I'm doing super. So it's hard to think of anything I've done wrong. I'd probably go back to 17 and tell my younger self take out a whole bunch of loans for college. Because in the future, a whole bunch of people are going to whine about how they didn't pick the right major and it's someone else's fault. And then we'll get them for free.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's true. That's so true. Tom?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: If I could talk to my younger self, I guess, I would say, Tommy get some of that hot lovin'.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I'm so disturbed by this answer.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: To be clear, just because it's you saying it.

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.utterance: Saying it to himself.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: And you call yourself "Tommy."

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.utterance: Does anyone else get the fact that he went back in time to seduce himself?

utterances.speaker: MACHI
utterances.utterance: Can I change my answer?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACHI
utterances.utterance: Go back and get some more of that hot lovin'.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: If I could go back in time, I would go back to when I was in eighth grade and don't believe the priest when he said that will make you go blind.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The weird thing is though, I am kind of legally blind. So maybe, maybe he was right. Anyway, next question is from Gerrie. She writes. Okay, so this -- she asks, what's your favorite movie, song and book? But for time, just pick one. What's your favorite movie, song or book? And I think I know what Kat is going to say. What's your favorite whatever?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: What's my favorite movie? Anybody here know? Come on. You don't know. Well, then, you don't know me at all. My favorite book, I'll go with that. "Rabbit at Rest" by John Updike.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Somebody reads. Wow, a real honest to God book. Her favorite movie is "Happy Gilmore."

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: It's true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Tom?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: I guess, favorite book maybe "Animal Farm" George Orwell, changed my life. It made me realize animals are a bunch of dirty communists.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Joe?

utterances.speaker: MACHI
utterances.utterance: "Lord of the Rings" for favorite book and movie. I should have got that hot lovin'.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Tyrus?

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.utterance: Hey, I'd be honest with you. I'm a little freaked out right now because "Animal Farm" was one of my favorite books because I like Boxer so much the character, but he said it, so now, I'm like "ew." So I have to go with "Where the Red Fern Grows" because that was my favorite book. Big Dan and Little Ann, man.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Where did the fern grow by the way?

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.utterance: See you'll not ruin it. Stop. Move on. The fern grew --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I didn't like any books that you were forced to read when you were young. Like I didn't like what's the "To Kill a Mockingbird." I didn't like that book.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Because you had to -- because they forced you to read it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, every book they forced me to read, I didn't like.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: You're an English major, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know. It's stupid.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: You're going to have to read some books.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I like "The Fall" by Albert Camus. Yes. I also like the "Bible of Unspeakable Truths" by Greg Gutfeld. You can get any paper back by the way. Oh, I'm shameless. Next question comes from Nathan. He tweeted to us, who are the crew that act in y'all skits because the whole crew is what seems to make the show. All right, first of all, it takes longer to write "y'all" than it is "you all." So enough of that as stupid affected "y'all" apostrophe crap. All right, I'll answer this. Everybody that you see the skits works on the show, because we're cheap. Yes, Tom, we don't pay you.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: N, I'm just in the building all the time. I've got nothing to do.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Always force feeding me those drugs.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's right. Every skit, he's on a drug. Yes. Anybody else want to answer that question? Who cares?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: It's a talented crew for -- I mean, this show -- is this not the best comedy show in late night?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: For the -- okay, if you look at any other shows, they've got a staff of like a hundred people. We have eight people and that's including the people in the couch. I mean, it's nuts.

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.utterance: And I'm part time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.utterance: Yes, you don't see me in the commercials because that's on a Wednesday and Tyrus don't work on Wednesdays.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, enough blowing our own horn. Sherlon went on our Facebook page and wants to know, what was everyone's first real job? Oh, all right, Machi, I have a feeling it was an interesting job.

utterances.speaker: MACHI
utterances.utterance: I worked at a fine dining restaurant where people were confused by why I was there.

utterances.speaker: MACHI
utterances.utterance: Yes, I just -- there's just something about me that doesn't say fine dining.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Kat, I have a feeling you worked and had an interesting experience.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: No, it wasn't interesting. I worked at a pizza and grinder shop. And I was maybe the only person who worked there that had never been to prison, so I didn't really fit in.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yet.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.utterance: I have a question.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.utterance: Grinder means a lot of things nowadays, so what -- pizza and what was the grinder part?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I had a shirt that I had to wear. That said "Gotta grab a grinder." But it was a sandwich.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Tom, first job?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: I worked in a nursing and retirement home. I lied to get in the job to get in the door. You were able to lie back then. Are you 16? I said, "Yes, I am 16." I was 15.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That gets me in a lot of trouble. You know, my first job -- I can't figure out which one was my first real job because there were like, I had a paper route. Is that a first real job?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I used to take pieces of to take sticks and put them together like crosses and go door to door and try and sell them. That doesn't count as a job. No one ever bought one.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That seems like a sick thing a child would do.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: You're not entirely wrong.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, that's weird. Selling sticks to strangers. Now, I was a paper route. Did some gardening for neighbors.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Grit? Did you ever sell subscriptions to neighbors?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I would never sell grit? I never knew what grit was.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: I gave it a try.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We add for grits. People in their 70s are going, "I know what Tom is talking about." All right, just shut up. Up next, it's the First Annual Greg Gutfeld Summer Movie Trivia Quiz.

utterances.speaker: AISHAH HASNIE, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: This is a Fox News Alert. I'm Aishah Hasnie in New York. Fox News has learned that billionaire Jeffrey Epstein has been charged by Federal prosecutors with sex trafficking. Epstein was arrested in the New York area and is now in police custody. He is expected to appear before a Federal Magistrate on Monday. At least 21 people were injured when a massive explosion rocked a South Florida shopping mall. The blast set large chunks of concrete flying through the air, scattering debris across a very busy road. A vacant pizza restaurant was destroyed and several businesses and cars damaged. One witness says it was like the world was ending. No word yet on what caused the blast, but firefighters found ruptured gas lines and none of the injuries are life threatening. I'm Aishah Hasnie, now back to The Greg Gutfeld Show. For all your headlines, log on to foxnews.com.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Time for the Summer Movie Trivia Quiz otherwise known as filler for a holiday show. Here's how we play. I ask multiple choice questions. You hold up paddles marked A, B, C or D to answer. The winner gets a copy of my book, "The Greg Garfield Monologues" which is now in paperback. Now in paperback. We can't afford prizes. Keep your own score. Here we go. All right first question, which movie is considered to be the first summer blockbuster film earning 100 mil in theaters. Is it A. "King Kong." B. "Raiders of the Lost Ark." C. "Godzilla." D. "Jaws." We got three rights. It was "Jaws."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Nicely done. Somebody is keeping score there, so that's one for Kat, one for Joe, one for Tom. Tyrus left out.

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.utterance: I'm not playing Greg. I'm putting the same letter up every time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, you're not doing it. You can't sulk during this.

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.utterance: Oh, I'm doing this. I'm not sulking. I am not playing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Why not?

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.utterance: You didn't ask me my job?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, all right. What was your first job?

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.utterance: No, so you can't go back now.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I am going to go.

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. All right. Question to "The Hustle" starring Anne Hathaway and Rebel Wilson is a remake of what film? A. "The Sting." B. "Dirty Rotten Scoundrels." C. "The Color of Money." D. "Lethal Weapon."

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Oh, who cares?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You guys have to play. Another three are right. Tyrus is right. Kat is right and Tom is right. Joe, you're wrong. It was "Dirty Rotten Scoundrels." Good. Let's see question three.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Maybe I'm psychic.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Best known for playing Luke Skywalker, what movie villain does Mark Hamill lend his voice to this summer? A. Is it Chucky? B. Is it Scar? C. Is it Ghost Face? D. Is it Jason Voorhees? Another three. Tyrus, Kat and Joe got it right. Kat in the lead. Kat is leading with three. You're going to win a copy of my book.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Oh, thank God.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And you'll find -- which heartthrob played Goose in "Top Gun"? A. Tom Cruise. B. Val Kilmer. C. Anthony Edwards. D. Lou Dobbs. The answer, oh Tyrus and Tom. Anthony Edwards. No Kat and no Joe. So now it's -- what's the score? It's Tom and Kat, Tyrus are tied up.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I've never seen a single one of these movies.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. Question five, Samuel Jackson stars in 2019's "Shaft." Who sang the original "Shaft" theme? Was it A. Marvin Gaye. B. Robert Goulet. C. Isaac Hayes. D Barry White. Oh, we've got another three right. Yes, Tyrus is right. Joe is right. Tom is right. Kat, you're wrong. Kat is losing the lead. Now Tyrus and Tom are ahead. This is just a load of --

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Where all the questions about "Happy Gilmore"?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Question six. Besides "Fletch," what Chevy Chase summer comedy was the biggest of 1985? A. "Three Amigos." B. "European Vacation." C. "Caddyshack." D. "Christmas Vacation." It's B. "European vacation." That means Joe and Tom get it right. Tom is in the lead now with five.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: I do host the "Quiz Show," Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, you're quite good at this. How many questions are we doing? Question seven. Will Smith plays the genie in the 2019 version of "Aladdin." Who voiced Iago in the 1992 animated version? Was it A. Jeremy Irons? B. Gilbert Godfrey. C. Rowan Atkinson. D. James Earl Jones. The answer. Oh, they all got it right with B. Last question. We need a tiebreaker here, kids. "I'm not bad. I'm just drawn that way," is a line from A. "Batman." B. "Terminator." C. "All in with Chris Hayes." Yes, it's kind of funny. D. "Who Framed Roger Rabbit." Who has this one? They all got him right which means the winner is Tom Shillue.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Tom gets a copy of my book which I will sign it. "Tom, I love you. Greg Gutfeld."

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Hey, it's that hot lovin' I was talking about.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, you got it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Coming up, our favorite fake ads, fake drugs, and fake movie trailers.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Let's look at the bits that made your side split. First up is a tourism add we made for Denver, Colorado after this city moved to decriminalize magic mushrooms.

utterances.speaker: ANNOUNCER
utterances.utterance: There's never been a better time to visit -- home of the Broncos, Coors, Lights, Mile-Hi. Skiing, Avalanche, Rocky Mountains, Skiing. Denver take a trip.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That -- we were trying to capture what it would be like if you were completely high on magic mushrooms and trying to do an ad. I think we caught it, right? You guys seem excited. All right. This next one is a product we imagined for the home, a room to hide from constant news media outrage. We called it the outrage bunker.

utterances.speaker: ANNOUNCER
utterances.utterance: In an era of volatile political storms, controversy can erupt at any moment without warning.

utterances.speaker: BROOKE BALDWIN, ANCHOR, CNN
utterances.utterance: Social media was quick to call the students involved racist.

utterances.speaker: ANNOUNCER
utterances.utterance: When outrage strikes, will you have the facilities to keep your family sane?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Oh my God. We have to get downstairs before it's too late.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Why? What's going on?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: There's no time. Get the kids. To the outrage bunker.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Come on kids, let's go.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Hold on, hold. I've got to SnapChat this.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Let's go. Come on. Be careful. Move fast. We've got to get in here. Come on.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Wait, wait. Wait. Open the door. Dad, Dad. Mom. It's your son, Billy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: We forgot Billy. You have to open the door. Quick.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: We can't. It's too late. If we open the door now, we get sucked into the outrage vortex. Billy is on his own now.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Guys, let's --

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: We can always have another.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Yes, I always hated Billy anyway.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I love you guys very much.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: He did drag us down.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Yes, I hate him. We can just wait out in the outrage bunker.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Please open this.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: It's for the best.

utterances.speaker: ANNOUNCER
utterances.utterance: The outrage bunkers impervious to Wi-Fi, hot takes, self- righteous diatribes, vilifying generalizations, stupefying story developments and all other hot air that comes with sensationalized breaking news stories. With the outrage bunker, you and your loved ones will be safe and healthy, so you can come out and enjoy life when the dust settles, as if that talk of the town never even happened.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Well, we made it. Billy?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Justice.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Billy, is it you, Billy? Holy mother of God.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: What the [bleep].

utterances.speaker: ANNOUNCER
utterances.utterance: So get outrage bunker today. Warning, outrage bunkers may provoke social media withdrawals, limited human interaction, new cycle apathy, and an increase in overall happiness.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, excellent acting. Excellent acting. Tom Shillue and our own Gene Nelson as the zombie. By the way, again, these are all people who work on our staff, have office jobs, no other -- could you imagine like Hannity staff doing this? Or Tucker staff? No.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: They can barely catch up football he throws.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's true. All right. Advertisers always use sex appeal to get people to buy their products. So we thought what would it look like if Trump tried that with his border wall? We got this.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Hey there, are you looking for the hottest border security this side of the Rio Grande? Do you love long, beautiful, slats? Raw, naked steel and sexy barriers that are see through in all the right places? Then you'll love the all new southern border wall. Perfect for stopping illegal flow of narcotics, criminals and migratory land mammals, because it can't be penetrated. There are other things walls are saying about the southern border wall. Fenway Park's Green Monster says --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I would totally bang that wall, bro.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Says the Great Wall of China.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Hey, if you're into older walls, call me.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: And the Great Barrier Reef says --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I haven't been this turned on since I had that three way with those tiger sharks.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: So call now because one way or another, these bricks are getting laid tonight.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, the narrator for that ad was our producer, Holly, who I think Tyrus now can never look at it the same way again. This last one is the scene we made from a new James Bond film that caters to the milkshake throwing activists in the U.K. Enjoy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Where are you? Where's the bomb? You can't get away with this.

utterances.speaker: TOM SHILLUE, FOX NATION HOST
utterances.utterance: Oh, but, James, I already have. By the time you track me down, it would be too late. Oh, James, you're so predictable. All I have to do is push this button and the building will be leveled.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: There's only one thing that can stop a madman like you. Wait.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, Tom. Before we go to break. That was one take.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: One take.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: One take.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: One take one shake.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I guess, we'll just end on that, right? Any other parting thoughts? No.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I'm good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Okay. Just checking it out.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: We really didn't bomb a building.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, we didn't. That was all acting.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That was all acting. Fake building. Up next, breakdancing may become an Olympic event, which means I'm about to win a gold medal.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Would the Olympics be shocking if they added popping and locking? The International Olympic Committee or IOC has provisionally approved adding breakdancing to the 2024 games in Paris. That's a city in France, Joe. Each dance battle will have 16 athletes competing in both the men's and women's events. Paris is also looking at skateboarding, sport climbing and surfing to their summer program. But the IOC has to grant final approval before the new sports can be added. Personally I'm still hoping this becomes an Olympic event.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Maybe the Russian judges gave her a 5.2. A little Russian judge over there. Joe, you seem like a break dancer.

utterances.speaker: MACHI
utterances.utterance: I am Greg and I'm pretty darn good at it. I'd demonstrate right now but I'm all mic'ed up, I can't.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACHI
utterances.utterance: But I'll tell you what, it's no wonder that the Olympics have bankrupted more cities than public unions because we're going through sports that are from other decades and no one really pays attention to them now. Why not add rollerblading or parkour.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Parkour.

utterances.speaker: MACHI
utterances.utterance: See, no one cares. That's exactly.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly. Kat, what are your thoughts on this breakdancing thing?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I think it's good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Good for you.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I think it's good because whenever I see anyone breakdancing, I look at them, and I think that looks hard. So I think that that should be in the Olympics. It looks harder than some of the other stuff that's already in the Olympics.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I agree, like the thing with the ribbons.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Like curling.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Curling. Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I actually don't know what curling is, Tyrus.

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.utterance: You better somebody, it's cool.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: You know, I actually feel like the fact that I've made it 30 years on this earth without ever needing to know tells me all I already need to know about curling.

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.utterance: You vape as a national pastime, so before you start talking about --

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: That needs to be --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That should be an event.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I can -- I can inhale --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The vape cloud. You get judged by the vape cloud.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I would win.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Of course you would. Of course you would. And they could -- you know what, that'd be great they could have it in San Francisco where it's banned.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Tyrus, what are your thoughts on this? It feels like sports are just arbitrary. Well, it's like why is baseball a sport?

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to get into that with you. Baseball is a great American pastime, communist. But here's the thing, the Olympics is -- it's dying and where they're trying to inject it with stuff to keep the old horse going, but at some point you've got to take Boxer to the glue factory. It's just the way it is. Breakdancing is an art form. You know, I put it up there with gymnastics and stuff, so I get it. I'm good with breakdancing. Badminton not so much, but you know the Olympics is trying to keep people going because once the Summer Olympics in this kind of thing, you see track and field and stuff. But countries as they progress and get better, they have their own sports now. And people don't -- the best athletes don't necessarily train for the Olympics. So it's kind of an -- it's an old pastime, but it's fading away. So eventually at some point it'll be video games. It'll be your face timing, speed texting. It will be things like that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Selfies. You could be judged on how well you disguise your flaws. Like that athlete comes out without makeup and then they do a selfie and if you can see how much better they are without actually knowing that they did anything. What am I talking about?

utterances.speaker: MURDOCH
utterances.utterance: You know you're onto something. It's one hundred percent. That's where the Olympics is going.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Or how about this? Speed texting, because like with the least error so you have like five people there and you have like a passage from "Paradise Lost" and they have to speak text it to their friend without -- with few errors.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I would win.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You would? Would you win?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: A thousand percent.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So there you go. See. It's right up your alley.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: And here I thought I was not an athlete.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, Tom, I bet you might have had some breakdancing in your background.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: I was a bit of a break dancer.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I could see that.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Yes, I was a bit of a foot looser, too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, were you?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Yes, I went to the art of feet loosing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Yes, letting those feet loose.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: But I --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Did you dismember people?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: I never did that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Okay.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: But, I thought about it. No. I used to hate the sports that had the judges. I like things that have finite, you know, rules to them. You know, if you run the fastest you get the gold medal. And I didn't think that anything that had judges in it should be in the Olympics, but now I do like the judging because it really shows you that there's no such thing as objectivity because the judges from Russia always give the Russian person the highest score.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: And it shows you there's no objectivity in the world.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is why as I've said before, all judges whether it's in sports, or in real life, have to be at robots or artificial intelligence, or what do you call those? What are those little things?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: You're going to have to be more specific.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Algorithms.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Of course.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because judges when they're like deciding whether you go to jail or not, it depends on whether they had lunch. There's research on that how much you ate affects whether you're going to get like pardons or early release and the same -- I mean, it's like it's so -- I mean, think about that? You've got to have -- it's the same thing with the Olympics. They've got to be judges.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: It also shows you, if you ever get arrested and you go into court bring a sandwich.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So true. So true. We learn a lot from you, Tom. All right. Don't forget to buy your tickets for "The Gutfeld Monologues Live." Stay right there. I have a very special "Final Thought" to close out tonight's show.

utterances.speaker: ANNOUNCER
utterances.utterance: "Final Thoughts." It's the last thought. That's why it's called the "Final Thoughts," okay.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. We've got two. One from Joe, go for it.

utterances.speaker: MACHI
utterances.utterance: Thanks, Greg. I just want to give a quick shout out to my friends at the Jared Box Project. What they do is they make up boxes of games and toys for kids fight in the hospital. It's Jared Box, thejaredbox.com. J- A-R-E-D. If you'd like to make a donation or get involved. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Nicely done. All right. So I have a "Final Thought." We are saying goodbye to a very important member of the staff. Come here. She is just going to cry. I know she is going to cry. Don't cry. Our studio audience coordinator, Nora Torpey. If you've ever been to a live show, which I think about 20,000 people have at this point, it's because Nora puts you there. Whenever you sent e-mails that were yelling about something, she was the one who had to read it and be nice to you. She's the one that always deals with cranky people who have to pee. She worked with us back in the "Red Eye" days and she's been a big part of this show's success. And we're going to miss you Nora. Give Nora a hand, everyone.

utterances.utterance: All right. Special thanks to Tom Shillue, Joe Machi, Kat, Tyrus and studio audience. Nora Torpey. I'm Greg Gutfeld. I love you, America.
